Hi David,

On Wed, Jan 6, 2010 at 10:08 AM, David Saff <david@...> wro=
te:

>
>
> Rocco,
>
> Note that these kinds of dependencies could be dynami=
cally inferred
> over time. With a complete history of pass/fail patterns, =
a core
> runner could notice that test B never passes when test A fails, an=
d
> that test A is failing today, and thus, mark B as "Skipped (98%
> confi=
dence of no new information after testA failed)"
>
> This seems like a real=
 win over manual dependency annotation, and I'd
> be delighted to take a lo=
ok at it if there were enough users (usual
> rules--create a github issue, =
and vote, vote, vote)
>
This doesn't seem very optimal since the knowledge =
can only be gained when
tests fail, which won't be the case most of the tim=
e.

Again, why leave this up to what seems like a difficult and unpredictab=
le
heuristic when it's so easy for users to explicitly state their dependen=
cies
in annotations?

--
